claim: Using a modified version of the two-rectangles paradigm (Egly et al., 1994), Hu et al. explored the extent to which animals and objects attract object-based attention (see Figure 1 for a schematic of their procedure).
title: Figure 1.
caption: A schematic representation of Hu et al.’s (2023) experimental paradigm.

claim: They included 12 images (see Figure 2): 6 animals (cat, sheep, rabbit, cow, moose, horse) and 6 objects (guitar, bowling pin, basketball, tent, trampoline, and a piano).
title: Figure 2.
caption: The target animals and objects used in the current study.

claim: Mean Euclidean distance error (Figure 3a): The main effects of Stimulus, F(1, 36) = 27.79, MSE = < 0.001, p < .001, η2p  = .44, and Distance, F(1, 36) = 11.31, MSE < 0.001, p = .002, η2p  = .24, were significant.
title: Figure 3.
caption: The mean recall performance in Experiment 1a for (a) mean Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (b) consistency of Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (c) the retrieval decision time for animals and objects in both near and far locations; and (d) proportion of targets correctly recalled in the displayed quadrant. All error bars represent ±95% CI.

claim: All error bars represent ±95% CI.Consistency of Euclidean distance error (see Figure 3b): The main effects of Stimulus F(1, 36) = 13.54, MSE = 34,979, p < .001, η2p  = .27 and Distance, F(1, 36) = 17.18, MSE = 42,258, p < .001, η2p = .32, both reached significance.
title: Figure 3.
caption: The mean recall performance in Experiment 1a for (a) mean Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (b) consistency of Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (c) the retrieval decision time for animals and objects in both near and far locations; and (d) proportion of targets correctly recalled in the displayed quadrant. All error bars represent ±95% CI.

claim: Retrieval decision time (see Figure 3c): The retrieval decision time data were transformed using a reciprocal transformation, prior to data analysis.
title: Figure 3.
caption: The mean recall performance in Experiment 1a for (a) mean Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (b) consistency of Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (c) the retrieval decision time for animals and objects in both near and far locations; and (d) proportion of targets correctly recalled in the displayed quadrant. All error bars represent ±95% CI.

claim: These data are shown in Figure 3d and were analysed using a Wilcoxon test (as these data did not meet the parametric assumptions [Shapiro–Wilk for the Animal recall was significant, p = .039]).
title: Figure 3.
caption: The mean recall performance in Experiment 1a for (a) mean Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (b) consistency of Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (c) the retrieval decision time for animals and objects in both near and far locations; and (d) proportion of targets correctly recalled in the displayed quadrant. All error bars represent ±95% CI.

claim:
Neither, the main effect of Distance, F(1, 34) = 0.21, MSE = 0.03, p = .647, η2p  < .01, nor the interaction between Stimulus and Distance, F(1, 34) = 0.18, MSE = 0.03, p = .675, η2p  < .01, reached significance.Retrieval
Mean Euclidean distance error (Figure 4a): The main effect of Stimulus, F(1, 34) = 22.39, MSE < 0.001, p < .001, η2p  = .40 was significant but the main effect of Distance was not, F(1, 34) = 0.45, MSE < 0.001, p = .506, η2p  = .01.
title: Figure 4.
caption: The mean recall performance in Experiment 1b for (a) mean Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (b) consistency of Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (c) the retrieval decision times for animals and objects in both near and far locations; and (d) proportion of targets correctly recalled in the displayed quadrant. All error bars represent ±95% CI.

claim: All error bars represent ±95% CI.Consistency of Euclidean distance error (see Figure 4b): The main effect of Stimulus, F(1, 34) = 4.80, MSE = 28,801, p = .035, η2p = .12, and Distance, F(1, 34) = 9.24, MSE = 35,752, p = .005, η2p  = .21, were both significant.
title: Figure 4.
caption: The mean recall performance in Experiment 1b for (a) mean Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (b) consistency of Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (c) the retrieval decision times for animals and objects in both near and far locations; and (d) proportion of targets correctly recalled in the displayed quadrant. All error bars represent ±95% CI.

claim: Retrieval decision time (see Figure 4c): The main effect of Stimulus was significant, F(1, 34) = 14.60, MSE = 0.002, p < .001, η2p  = .30, but the main effect of Distance was not, F(1, 34) = 0.13, MSE = 0.003, p = .720, η2p < .01.
title: Figure 4.
caption: The mean recall performance in Experiment 1b for (a) mean Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (b) consistency of Euclidean distance error for animals and objects in both near and far locations; (c) the retrieval decision times for animals and objects in both near and far locations; and (d) proportion of targets correctly recalled in the displayed quadrant. claim: These data (see Figure 5) predominantly show a consistent story.
title: Figure 5.
caption: The mean Euclidean distance error for each target item pooled across Experiments 1a and 1b. The error bars represent 95% CI.

claim: These data are presented separately for animals and objects and are shown in Figure 6.
title: Figure 6.
caption: Scatterplots depicting the relationship between ease of collection rating and mean Euclidean distance error for individual targets in the pooled data from Experiments 1a and 1b for (a) animals and (b) objects. The grey bands represent 95% confidence intervals.

claim: These data can be seen in Figure 7.
title: Figure 7.
caption: Scatterplots depicting the relationship between encoding decision time and mean Euclidean distance error for individual targets in the pooled Experiments 1a and 1b data for (a) animals only, and (b) objects only. The grey bands represent 95% confidence intervals.

claim:
